newsitem.title: ITALY: FOCUS-Italy seeks to close metalworkers' deal.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Italy seeks to close metalworkers' deal.

text.p: The Italian government said on Friday it believed an end was in sight to a protracted pay dispute in the engineering and metalworking industry and summoned union and business chiefs for talks on Monday.

"The government has noted...fresh readiness to seek agreements in order to conclude the negotiations," said a government statement issued after Prime Minister Romano Prodi met leaders of the country's three main trades union confederations.
It said it would call a meeting of the three union bodies, CGIL, CISL and UIL, and the employers' umbrella group Confindustria "as a matter of priority."
Labour Minister Tiziano Treu, who attended the Prodi talks, said the meeting had been set for Monday "in order to begin a decisive discussion".
"The climate has changed in a positive sense. Today we have seen there is a will to reach the last lap," Treu said.
The dispute, which involves some 1.7 million workers, is expected to set the tone for pay deals in a number of other Italian industrial sectors.

The unions in the sector, FIOM, FIM and UILM, have already staged three one-day stoppages to press their claims for increases in wages for the 1996-98 period since the previous contracts expired last June.
The government suggested in December that management give workers an average 200,000 lire ($125) per month pay increase.

Unions, which had been seeking a 230,000 lire increase, accepted the proposals but the main industry group Federmeccanica has stuck to its original 139,000 lire offer, saying it will not accept a deal that fuels inflation.
Federmeccanica president Gabriele Albertini said in Bologna on Friday that he thought the prospects for striking a deal had never been better.
"For the first time in 25 years, we have the opportunity to renew a contract in a non-inflationary way. Let's hope this objective can be reached in the coming days," he said.
The optimism was tempered, however, by continued differences between employers and unions over whether the government proposal was inflationary. Prodi says it is not.
The dispute centres on the interpretation of a landmark wage deal in July 1993 between the labour confederations, Confindustria and the government which scrapped automatic index-linked wage rises.
The two sides differ over the extent to which workers should be compensated for loss of purchasing power since the last contract was signed.

"What's new is that Federmeccanica is saying, contrary to what it said before, that it wants to conclude a contract. That is a step forward which we welcome but it is not enough," CGIL leader Sergio Cofferati said.
"The settlement reached must be in line with the July accord," he said.
The dispute has weighed on monetary policy, with Bank of Italy governor Antonio Fazio waiting to cut interest rates until he was satisified that any deal would not fuel inflation.
He acted on Tuesday, announcing a cut in the key discount rate to 6.75 percent from 7.50 percent after preliminary inflation data for January showed a year-on-year rise of 2.6 percent.
